msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: William Lewis Sharkey served as Mississippi’s governor in 1865, early in the Reconstruction era.

Born in Sumner County, Tennessee, on July 12, 1798, Sharkey moved with his family to Warren County, Mississippi, in 1804. As an adult, he studied law and began practicing in Natchez, Mississippi, in 1822. Sharkey moved to Vicksburg in 1825 and pursued political office. He won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives and served one term from 1828 to 1829.

In 1832, Sharkey married Minerva Cage, a widow with two children. The couple had four children over the next several years. In 1832, Sharkey also became a circuit court judge and was shortly thereafter elected to the High Court of Errors and Appeals, the predecessor to the Supreme Court of Mississippi. He served in that role for 18 years, resigning in 1851. From there, he took a diplomatic appointment for the United States government, serving as U.S. Consul in Havana, Cuba, until 1854. After completing that diplomatic assignment, Sharkey returned to Mississippi and returned to legal and political duties, helping compile the Mississippi Code of 1857.

During the secession crisis in the winter of 1860 and 1861, following Abraham Lincoln’s election, Sharkey remained a steadfast Unionist. Having been a member of the Whig Party, he retained his opposition to secession and refused to support the Confederacy, even as he remained in Mississippi through the Civil War. Despite his political stance against Mississippi’s secessionist government, Confederate officials left him alone out of respect of his past service to the state as a judge and legal scholar.

After the Confederacy’s defeat, President Andrew Johnson appointed Sharkey provisional governor of Mississippi in June 1865. In that role, he called forth a constitutional convention to meet Johnson’s goal of swiftly restoring former Confederate states to the Union. In October 1865, Benjamin Humphreys won election as Mississippi’s governor. Sharkey did not vacate the office, though, until December 1865, having served less than a year. Although no longer governor, Sharkey was selected by the Mississippi legislature to serve in the U.S. Senate. Federal officials denied him a seat, and the rest of the Mississippi congressional delegation, following the Republican backlash to Mississippi’s Black Codes—a set of racially discriminatory laws passed by the Mississippi legislature in 1865.

Having been denied a U.S. Senate seat, Sharkey returned to practicing law, in Jackson, Mississippi. He died in Washington, D.C., on March 30, 1873, and is buried at Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “William Lewis Sharkey: Twenty-fifth Governor of Mississippi: June to December 1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)
William Lewis Sharkey belonged to the following social groups:
Hugh McCulloch was a businessman, banker, and U.S. Secretary of the Treasury in the nineteenth century.

Born in Kennebunk, Maine, on December 7, 1808, McCulloch was educated in New England before moving to Fort Wayne, Indiana, in 1833 to practice law. Shortly afterwards, in 1835, he began working at the Bank of Indiana, rising from cashier to manager of the Fort Wayne branch, then to president of the overall company. He remained at the bank until 1863, when he was appointed by Secretary of the Treasury Salmon P. Chase to be Comptroller of the Currency. McCulloch proved very capable in that role, recommending changes to banking laws and seeing widespread success among banks in the northern states.

In March 1865, President Abraham Lincoln offered McCulloch the position of Secretary of the Treasury. He reluctantly accepted the job, and proved successful at reducing the national debt. He opposed the widespread use of paper currency and labored to reduce paper bills in circulation. The effort was not popular and was eventually halted by Congress. When his term as secretary ended in 1869, McCulloch moved to England and worked as a partner in the banking firm of Jay Cooke, McCulloch & Co. McCulloch was called again to public service in 1884, when President Chester A. Arthur appointed him as Secretary of the Treasury. He served only six months, until March 1885, when Arthur’s presidential term ended.

McCulloch died on May 24, 1895. He had been married twice, first to Eunice Hardy who died in 1836, only two years after their wedding. He then married Susan Man in 1838 and had at least five children. McCulloch is buried in Rock Creek Cemetery in Washington, D.C.
Hugh McCulloch belonged to the following social groups:

Located in Orleans Parish, New Orleans was founded in 1718. It became the capital of French Louisiana in 1722 and continued as the capital when Louisiana achieved statehood on April 30, 1812. It became part of Orleans County (now extinct) on the same day. In 1849 it was replaced by Baton Rouge as the state capital, although it temporarily served as the capital again from 1865 until 1880. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)

Located between Maryland & Virginia on the Potomac River, the Territory of Columbia was established on July 16, 1790 under the name Federal City and was renamed Washington City in the 1800s. The city of Washington became the federal capital on February 27, 1801 and established as Washington, D.C. on February 24, 1801, when the city boundaries were expanded to include the entire Federal District of Columbia. Washington, D.C. has never achieved statehood. (Wikipedia, Britannica)

gloss.p: "The act of stopping fighting and officially admitting defeat." (Cambridge Dictionary)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America--Military Service (Branch Unspecified)
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The military forces of the Confederate States of America (1861-1865) consisted of the Army, Navy, and Marine Corps and were responsible for the defense of the Confederacy and securing the nation's independence. While definitive numbers are not available, the Confederacy's Army ranged between 750,000–1,500,000 soldiers and 483,026 casualties. (Wikipedia; National Park Service)
A representative of "the government department responsible for financial matters such as spending and taxes." (Cambridge Dictionary)

The Congress of the Confederate States of America was established by Article 1 of the Confederate States Constitution on March 11, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, it was the Legislative Branch of the Confederate States government responsible for making and amending laws. A bicameral body, the Confederate States Congress was divided into the upper house (Senate) and the lower house (House of Representatives). The Confederate States Congress concluded Its final session on March 18, 1865. (Avalon Project-Constitution of the Confederate States; March 11, 1861; Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: United States--United States Military Telegraph Office (Washington, D.C.)
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Organizations -- U.S. Federal Government
Organizations -- Military Organizations

gloss.p: Located in the War Department building in Washington, D. C., the United States Military Telegraph Office was a centralized office created in 1861. The United States Military Telegraph Office served as the headquarters for the United States Military Corps where ciphers coded and decoded messages, maintaining communications between the federal government in Washington D. C. and the commanding officers of the Union Army on the warfront. (Wikipedia; "The War Effort: The Telegraph Office," Mr. Lincoln's White House)

Operating at the national level, the Department of the Treasury is the national treasury and finance department of the federal government of the United States, where it serves as an executive department. It was created in 1789 and is located in Washington D.C. (Wikipedia)

element.label: Description
element.value: From the Mississippi Department of Archives and History Governor Sharkey Collection. Telegram from United States Secretary of the Treasury Hugh McCulloch at Washington, District of Columbia, to Mississippi Governor William L. Sharkey, concerning the disposition of Confederate cotton.

div.fw: Telegram from Secretary of the Treasury Hugh McCulloch to Mississippi Governor William L. Sharkey; August 4, 1865
div.p:
U. S. Military Telegraph Office,
New Orleans Jackson Aug 5 1865

By Telegraph from Washington 4
To Gov. Sharkey

Treasury agents are instructed to secure the cotton which belonged to the Confederate government & which was included in the property surrendered by rebel generals doubtfully cases should be reported here
